c-basics-01.title: Introduction to Algorithms
c-basics-01.description: Learn the basics of algorithms, their history, and why they are so powerful.
c-basics-01.content: An algorithm is a finite sequence of well-defined, computer-implementable instructions, typically to solve a class of problems or to perform a computation. Algorithms are always unambiguous and are used as specifications for performing calculations, data processing, automated reasoning, and other tasks.

exercise.question: Write a simple 'Hello, World!' algorithm in pseudocode.

c-syntax-02.title: Pseudocode Syntax
c-syntax-02.description: Understand the basic syntax for writing algorithms in pseudocode.
c-syntax-02.content: Pseudocode is an informal high-level description of the operating principle of a computer program or other algorithm. It uses the structural conventions of a normal programming language, but is intended for human reading rather than machine reading. There's no strict syntax, but clarity is key.

exercise.question: Fix the pseudocode to correctly describe printing 'Algo is fun!'

c-variables-03.title: Algorithm Variables
c-variables-03.description: Understand how to declare and use variables to store data in your algorithms.
c-variables-03.content: Variables are containers for storing data values. In algorithms, we often declare them with a type and a name, for example: `DECLARE myNum as INTEGER`. We can then assign values, like `SET myNum to 15`.

exercise.question: Declare an integer variable, assign it the value 42, and output it.

c-data-types-04.title: Algorithm Data Types
c-data-types-04.description: Explore the different data types used in algorithms for storing various kinds of data.
c-data-types-04.content: A data type specifies the type of data that a variable can store. Common types include INTEGER, REAL (for floating-point numbers), CHARACTER, and STRING. Choosing the right data type is important for correctness and efficiency.

exercise.question: Create variables for an integer, a real number, and a character, and output their values.

c-operators-05.title: Algorithm Operators
c-operators-05.description: Learn about arithmetic, assignment, comparison, and logical operators in algorithms.
c-operators-05.content: Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values. These include arithmetic (+, -, *, /), assignment (SET...TO), comparison (=, <>, >), and logical (AND, OR, NOT) operators.

exercise.question: Write an algorithm that uses the multiplication operator to multiply two numbers and print the result.

c-control-flow-06.title: Control Flow (If...Else)
c-control-flow-06.description: Learn to control the flow of your algorithm using conditional statements.
c-control-flow-06.content: Use `IF...THEN` to specify a block of instructions to be executed if a condition is true. Use `ELSE` to specify a block of instructions to be executed if the condition is false. Use `ELSE IF` to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false.

exercise.question: Write an algorithm to check if a number is positive or negative.

c-switch-07.title: Switch/Case Statement
c-switch-07.description: Learn to use the switch/case statement for multi-way branching.
c-switch-07.content: The switch statement allows a variable to be tested for equality against a list of values. Each value is called a case. It's a cleaner alternative to long `if-else if-else` chains. A `DEFAULT` case can handle all other values.

exercise.question: Write an algorithm that outputs the name of a month based on its number (1-12).

c-loops-08.title: Loops (For & While)
c-loops-08.description: Master loops to execute a block of instructions multiple times.
c-loops-08.content: Loops execute a block of code as long as a specified condition is met. The `WHILE` loop continues as long as a condition is true. The `FOR` loop is great when you know the number of iterations in advance.

exercise.question: Use a `WHILE` loop to output numbers from 1 to 10.

c-arrays-09.title: Arrays
c-arrays-09.description: Learn to store multiple values of the same type in an array.
c-arrays-09.content: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable. To declare an array, you specify the name, the type of data, and the size. Elements are accessed via an index, usually starting from 0 or 1.

exercise.question: Declare an array of 3 integers, assign values, and output the second element.

c-pointers-10.title: Pointers & References
c-pointers-10.description: Understand the powerful concept of pointers and memory references.
c-pointers-10.content: A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of another variable. This allows for indirect manipulation of data and is fundamental to many advanced data structures and algorithms. It's a key concept for efficiency.

exercise.question: Describe in pseudocode how you would change a variable's value using a pointer.

c-functions-11.title: Functions/Procedures
c-functions-11.description: Learn to create and use functions to structure your algorithms.
c-functions-11.content: A function (or procedure) is a block of code which only runs when it is called. You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function. Functions are crucial for reusing code and breaking down complex problems into smaller, manageable pieces.

exercise.question: Create a function named `greet` that outputs 'Hello there!' and call it.

c-structs-12.title: Structs/Records
c-structs-12.description: Combine different data types into a single user-defined type.
c-structs-12.content: Structures (or records) are a way to group several related variables into one place. Each variable in the structure is a member or field. This is useful for representing real-world objects with multiple properties.

exercise.question: Define a record for a `Car` with fields for `brand` (string) and `year` (integer). Create an instance and output its year.

c-recursion-13.title: Recursion
c-recursion-13.description: Learn how a function can call itself to solve problems.
c-recursion-13.content: Recursion is the technique of making a function call itself. This provides a way to break complicated problems down into simple problems which are easier to solve. A recursive function must have a base case that stops the recursion, or it will loop infinitely.

exercise.question: Write a recursive function to calculate the factorial of a number.

c-constants-14.title: Constants
c-constants-14.description: Learn how to define variables that cannot be changed.
c-constants-14.content: If you have a variable that should not be changed, you can use the `const` keyword. This will declare the variable as 'constant', which means that it is unchangeable and read-only. This is useful for values that are known to be fixed, like PI.

exercise.question: Declare a constant for PI and print it.

c-booleans-15.title: Booleans
c-booleans-15.description: Learn about the boolean data type for true/false values.
c-booleans-15.content: A boolean variable is declared with the `bool` keyword and can only take the values `true` or `false`. When the value is returned, `true` = 1 and `false` = 0. You must include the `<stdbool.h>` header file to use this type.

exercise.question: Declare a boolean variable for `isLightOn` and set it to false, then print its value.

c-break-continue-16.title: Break and Continue
c-break-continue-16.description: Understand how to control the flow inside loops.
c-break-continue-16.content: The `break` statement can be used to jump out of a `switch` statement or a loop. The `continue` statement breaks one iteration in the loop, if a specified condition occurs, and continues with the next iteration in the loop.

exercise.question: Write a loop from 0 to 9, but use `continue` to skip printing the number 5.

c-strings-17.title: Strings
c-strings-17.description: Learn how to work with text using strings.
c-strings-17.content: Strings are used for storing text/characters. Unlike many other programming languages, C does not have a String type to easily create string variables. Instead, you must use a `char` array and null-terminate it.

exercise.question: Create a string variable that holds the value 'Volvo' and print it.

c-function-parameters-18.title: Function Parameters
c-function-parameters-18.description: Learn how to pass data to functions.
c-function-parameters-18.content: Information can be passed to functions as a parameter. Parameters act as variables inside the function. You can add as many parameters as you want, just separate them with a comma.

exercise.question: Create a function that takes two integers and prints their sum.

c-user-input-19.title: User Input
c-user-input-19.description: Learn how to get input from the user.
c-user-input-19.content: The `scanf()` function is used to get user input. It takes two arguments: the format specifier of the variable (`%d`, `%c`, etc.) and the reference operator `&` on the variable to store the input.

exercise.question: Write a program that asks for the user's first name and then greets them.

c-enums-20.title: Enums
c-enums-20.description: Learn to create your own data type with a set of constant values.
c-enums-20.content: An `enum` is a special type that represents a group of constants (unchangeable values). To create an enum, use the `enum` keyword, followed by the name of the enum, and separate the enum items with a comma.

exercise.question: Create an enum for `Status` with values for PENDING, APPROVED, and REJECTED, then print the numeric value of APPROVED.
